title: 105_hr4102
content: The "Child Care for Working Parents Act of 1998" may be cited as the Act. It includes an Early Childhood Education Services Referral Hotline. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may grant funds to a nonprofit entity to operate a national hotline providing information on early childhood education services. The grant can last up to 5 years and requires annual approval. The entity must use the funds to establish and run the hotline. To operate the hotline, a nonprofit entity must contract with a carrier for a toll-free line, employ personnel to provide information on early childhood education facilities, maintain a database of local services, and promote the hotline nationwide. An application for a grant must be approved by the Secretary and include necessary agreements and assurances. The application for a grant to operate a national early childhood education services referral hotline must include agreements, assurances, and information as required by the Secretary. It should also detail the operation plan, training program for hotline personnel, accuracy methodology, publicity plan, expertise in early childhood education, and support from advocacy groups. Additional information may be required by the Secretary. Authorization of Appropriations: $1,000,000 for fiscal year 1999, $400,000 for each fiscal year from 2000 to 2004. Funds remain available until expended. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE CHILD CARE AND DEVELOPMENT BLOCK GRANT ACT OF 1990. Amendments to the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 include authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 1999 through 2002, timely payment of funds for child care services, and child care quality improvement. Child Care Quality Improvement section of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended. The Child Care Quality Improvement section of the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include activities aimed at enhancing the quality of child care. The State receiving financial assistance must allocate at least 4 percent for resource and referral programs, grants or loans to meet standards, and monitoring compliance with licensing and regulatory requirements related to child care. Improving monitoring of compliance with State and local licensing requirements, providing training in health and safety, nutrition, and child abuse prevention, and enhancing compensation for child care staff. Amendments do not apply to fiscal years before enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. CREDIT FOR EMPLOYER EXPENSES IN PROVIDING CERTAIN DEPENDENT CARE SERVICES. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow for employer expenses in providing dependent care services. The employer day care center credit under section 38 is determined for each qualified day care center of the taxpayer. The credit is 50 percent of the excess of expenses for providing dependent care services over the amount received for such services. The qualified day care center must be operated exclusively for providing dependent care services to employees, located on or near the business premises, compliant with all relevant laws, and part of a dependent care assistance program. The tax code is amended to include a new employer day care center credit under section 38. Additionally, a denial of double benefit is specified for employer day care center expenses under section 280C to prevent a deduction equal to the credit amount. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of the tax code. The tax code is amended to include a new employer day care center credit under section 38. Additionally, a denial of double benefit is specified for employer day care center expenses under section 280C to prevent a deduction equal to the credit amount. Part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of such Code is amended by adding at the end the following new item. The tax code is amended to provide a new employer day care center credit under section 38. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act. Additionally, there is an extended time for learning and longer school year under Section 10993(h)(1) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
